awd_titl_txt: MRI-R2: Acquisition for the Critical Infrastructure Security and Assessment Laboratory (CISAL)
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5). 

A strong need for research activities on critical infrastructure protection motivated the establishment of a research facility at Jacksonville State University (JSU) whose primary purpose is to investigate, develop, implement, and assess security technologies for critical infrastructure protection. This cross-disciplinary project undertaken by the Mathematical, Computer and Information Sciences (MCIS) and the Engineering and Technology departments represents a novel approach of establishing a cybersecurity-focused research laboratory facility that emulates multiple configurations of real industrial control systems. 

The project builds upon the existing STEM knowledge base in the areas of network security, risk assessment, security compliance, industrial controls, and digital forensic analysis to enhance existing and develop new security technologies in an area of national need.  The lessons learned and the experiences gained in designing and utilizing the facility will provide a blueprint for the design of similar facilities in medium to large sized institutions of higher education. A key component of this project is the collaborative effort that will take place between JSU, area community colleges, and industrial partners in maximizing the utilization of the proposed research facility through active collaborations. 

The creation of new and the adoption of existing STEM knowledge nuggets, including the creative research techniques in security, networks, and industrial controls, will provide exemplary materials to institutions with diverse demographics. JSU, having been recently designated by the National 
Security Agency (NSA) as a National Center of Academic Excellence in Information Assurance Education, is in a unique position of being able to contribute to broadening the participation of the underrepresented groups through the diversity of its student population.  In addition, this project will target smaller institutions of learning, including institutions that traditionally serve underrepresented groups, as future collaborators.  

The collaboration between JSU, area community colleges and industrial partners can serve as a model for future collaborations between institutions of higher learning and the industrial sector.  The results of our research and project evaluation will be disseminated using a dedicated Web server ? a cost-effective approach to closing the gap between those who have access to rich learning opportunities and those who do not.  We will initiate a pilot workshop for community college instructors and industry personnel on the utilization and capability of the research facility.   Since the reach of this project can extend beyond STEM disciplines, the project will also provide orientation workshops to faculty members of other disciplines to stimulate a cross-pollination of research methods and ideas that will impact information security.

por.por_cntn:
This cross-disciplinary project undertaken by the Mathematical, Computer and Information Sciences (MCIS) and the Engineering and Technology departments at Jacksonville State University presents a novel approach of establishing a cybersecurity-focused research laboratory facility that emulates multiple configurations of real industrial control systems.

The project successfully integrated research activities with experiential learning on a contemporary and highly relevant area of national need: security of critical infrastructures. The project built upon the existing STEM knowledge base in the areas of network security, risk assessment, security compliance, industrial controls, and digital forensic analysis to enhance existing and develop new security technologies in the area. Risk assessment of control systems were investigated and brought to light through published papers. The lessons learned and the experiences gained in designing and utilizing the Critical Infrastructure Laboratory facility were also published and should be able to provide a blueprint for the design of similar facilities in medium to large sized institutions of higher education. A significant contribution of the project is the design and implementation of a Control Systems Security Toolkit. The toolkit includes application software that was developed in the laboratory to automate the process of simulating operator actions in an existing Human Machine Interface (HMI) of a Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) system. The project also demonstrated, with multiple proof-of-concept penetration attacks, the vulnerabilities of various wired and wireless protocols. Prominent proof-of-concepts attacks include denial-of-service on both wired and wireless devices, breaking of authentication keys, and service discoveries/monitoring. These results were documented and published in a conference proceeding.  Further, industrial partners were invited to peruse the facility and to provide insights on the possible utilization of the equipment as a test bed for control system security and product/system evaluation. The facility also provides the necessary infrastructure to enable advanced research on critical infrastructure protection. Proposed collaborative research activities with other institutions and industry partners have been initiated.

Portable SCADA systems were designed and developed to enable off-site training of community college instructors and industrial partners on cybersecurity. This should facilitate the project’s broader impact on a very diverse community of learners for years to come. The experiences and the lessons gained in developing the portable toolkits were documented and published in an engineering journal. Plans for an annual and on-site training workshop are underway to further the dissemination of the project results.

In summary, we believe that this project provided and will continue to deliver significant contributions toward the protection of our critical infrastructures at this critical juncture of our nation’s history.
